node.text:
As New Yorkers commemorate the 20th anniversary of 9/11, they are also contemplating how to recover from covid-19.

After the attacks of 2001, New York came back stronger—so what lessons can its leaders learn from that success to help the city bounce back today?

Cover image credit: Gary Hershorn/Getty Images

node.title: From 9/11 to covid-19: can New York recover?

node.text:
The pandemic not only disrupted education—it also thrust technology onto a sector which historically has been slow to adopt it. Will classrooms ever be the same again?

Cover image credit: Ben Hasty/MediaNews Group/Reading Eagle via Getty Images

node.title: Covid-19: how tech will transform your kids’ education

buttons.text: Visit the COVID-19 Information Center for vaccine resources.

node.text: The race between covid-19 vaccines and variants is on. Alok Jha, The Economist’s science correspondent, and Natasha Loder, our health policy editor, discuss what this means for the future. Cover image credit: Alamy

node.title: Covid-19: can vaccines keep up with variants?

node.text: The Taliban’s swift return to power in Afghanistan has shocked the world and humiliated America. What effect will this have on the international standing of the US and on global security? Our experts answer your questions. Cover credit: AP

node.title: Afghanistan: how the Taliban weakened America

node.text:
Most governments recognise that vaccination is the fastest way out of the pandemic, but in many places hesitancy is hindering the roll-out. Should employers—or even governments—force people to have the vaccine? We answer your questions.

Cover image credit:

node.text:
The covid-19 pandemic has reinforced humanity’s dependence on modern tech, but the same tools that enable remote working are also being used to spread disinformation and perpetuate cybercrime. Ambivalence towards technology is nothing new.

Cover image credit: Scott Strazzante/The San Francisco Chronicle via Getty Images

node.text:
In the past couple of weeks South Africa has witnessed the worst violence since the end of apartheid in 1994. Our correspondent in Johannesburg explains what he has seen on the streets and why the country is in crisis. 

Cover credit: Getty Images

node.title: South Africa: what's behind the riots?

node.text:
In America, the intelligence services deem far-right extremism a greater domestic threat than Islamist terrorism. The pandemic has exacerbated the spread of white supremacism and neo-Nazism.

Cover image credit: Michael Nigro/Pacific Press/LightRocket via Getty Images

node.title: Fortnite to far right: the rise of digital extremism

node.text:
Across much of the world, covid-19 restrictions are starting to ease. The Economist has crunched the data to calculate how close countries are to pre-pandemic levels of normality—but will life ever be the same again? 

Click on the link in our bio to visit our website and explore our interactive normalcy tracker. It covers 50 countries which account for 76% of the world’s population and 90% of its GDP.

Cover image credit: Lluis Gene/AFP via Getty Images

node.title: Covid-19: why your life will never be the same again

node.text:
The world’s animals and wildlife are going extinct at a greater rate than at any time in human history. Can technology help turn the tide?

Cover image credit: Yashpal Rathore/Nature Picture Library

node.title: Mass extinction: what can stop it?

node.text: The number of working-age people in China is shrinking. Could this threaten the country’s rise as an economic superpower? Credit: Eyevine

node.title: China’s economy: what’s its weak spot?

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist in London, United Kingdom. May be an image of text that says '"It " It seems as if the surest way to curse one's nation is to subordinate its women Authors of a study that ranks 176 countries for misogyny'.

node.text:
Researchers have found patriarchy to be a better predictor of violent instability than income, urbanisation or bad governance.⁠
⁠
The study, by Valerie Hudson, Donna Lee Bowen and Perpetua Lynne Nielsen of Texas A&M and Brigham Young universities, estimates that 120 countries are still to some degree swayed by pre-modern attitudes to women that endanger political stability.⁠
⁠
If women are subject to autocracy and terror in their homes, society is also more vulnerable to these ills. ⁠
⁠
A composite measure of archaic attitudes to women explained three-quarters of the variation in a country’s score on the Fragile States index compiled by the Fund for Peace. ⁠
⁠
The researchers also found evidence that patriarchy and poverty go hand in hand.⁠
⁠
To read how the most sexist societies work, and why oppressing women comes at a great cost, click on the link in our bio.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on September 14, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Asia A journey from Kabul to Kandahar, a month after the Taliban took power'.

node.text:
This is part of the nearly 500km section of Highway 1 that links Afghanistan’s capital, Kabul, to its second city, Kandahar. Just weeks ago, this was a perilous route.⁠
⁠
Taliban fighters held up traffic, ambushed convoys and killed government workers.⁠
⁠
Now the very fighters who once attacked the road are standing guard along it. ⁠
⁠
There are deep ruts in the decaying asphalt. The traffic passes the ghosts of American posts as it slaloms around craters left by roadside bombs. ⁠
⁠
A month after the Islamists took power, the journey from Kabul to Kandahar gives an illustration both of how the country changed overnight and of the failures that helped bring about the change.⁠
⁠
Click on the link in our bio to read our correspondent’s account, and what it says about Afghanistan’s old problems and new challenges.⁠
⁠
Credit: Marcus Yam, Los Angeles Times

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on September 14, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and text.

node.text:
It seemed like a blustery overpromise when President Joe Biden pledged in July to oversee “the largest ever one-year decrease in child poverty in the history of the United States”. By the end of the year, however, he will probably turn out to have been correct.⁠
⁠
Recent modelling by scholars at Columbia University estimates that in July child poverty was 41% lower than normal.⁠
⁠
The number of households with children that reported not having enough food in the past week dropped substantially after the first child-tax-credit payment began—going from 13.7% to 9.5%. At full coverage, poverty for black children would drop from its present estimate of 18.4% to 13.6%; for Hispanic children from 16.8% to 14.1%.⁠
⁠
Tap the link in our bio to read why the Biden administration’s biggest success has not received enough attention.⁠
⁠
Credit: Eyevine

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist in Bali. May be an image of nature.

node.text:
“Hybrid” reefs have been around for a while, but now they are being deployed in surprising ways.⁠
⁠
Artificial coral reefs co-opt the local ecology to help out. Fully grown, they are a defence against erosion and wave damage—and a tourist attraction for divers.⁠
⁠
In a warming world with rising sea levels, coral reef defence is likely to have widespread appeal. However, even artificial reefs are not immune to climate change. ⁠
⁠
Perhaps the biggest challenge is to ensure that hybrid reefs survive altered environmental conditions, including seawater that is getting warmer and more acidic. ⁠
⁠
To read why hybrid reefs are gaining the attention of commercial developers, and even the military, tap the link in our bio. ⁠
⁠
Credit: Alamy

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on September 14, 2021. May be an image of 1 person and text that says 'German election 2021 Olaf Scholz is a serious contender to replace Angela Merkel. How would he lead?'.

node.text:
Olaf Scholz’s chances of entering Germany’s chancellery are rising. ⁠
⁠
According to our election forecast, his centre-left Social Democratic Party (SPD) has around a three in four chance of being the largest party in the Bundestag, with just under two weeks to go.⁠
⁠
Although Germans cannot vote for their chancellor directly, Mr Scholz is much more popular than either of his main rivals, Armin Laschet, of Angela Merkel’s conservative Christian Democratic Union (CDU) and its Bavarian ally, the Christian Social Union (CSU); and Annalena Baerbock, of the Greens. ⁠
⁠
It is an impressive rise for Mr Scholz, who in the early 2000s was dubbed “Scholz-o-mat” for his robotic demeanour. ⁠
⁠
But who is he, and what kind of Germany does he want to lead? To find out, tap on the link in our bio.⁠ #BTW21⁠
⁠
Credit: Sebastian Gollnow / DPA

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on September 14, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Our daily estimate of excess deaths around the world September 14th 2021 Estimated global excess deaths With 95% confidence interval 9.5m 15.4m 18.4m 2.1x Official global covid-19 deaths 3.3x official deaths 4x 4.6m Sources: Johns Hopkins University CSSE; The Economist's excess-deaths model The Economist'.

node.text:
Although the official number of deaths caused by covid-19 is now 4.6m, our single best estimate using our excess deaths model is that the actual toll is 15.4m people.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Many people who die while infected with coronavirus are never tested for it, and do not enter the official totals.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Some people whose deaths have been attributed to covid-19 had other ailments that might have ended their lives on a similar timeframe anyway. And what about people who died of preventable causes during the pandemic, because hospitals full of covid-19 patients could not treat them?⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Rather than trying to distinguish between types of deaths, The Economist’s approach is to count all of them. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Our data journalists have built a machine-learning model, which estimates excess deaths for every country on every day since the pandemic began, based both on official excess-mortality data and on more than 100 other statistical indicators. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
To explore the numbers by country, tap the link in our bio

node.text:
What does Taliban control mean for Afghanistan’s opium economy?⁠
⁠
The country produces 90% of the world’s illegal opium, the tacky gum harvested from poppies that can be turned into heroin.⁠
⁠
Today the opium trade is worth between 6% and 11% of Afghanistan’s GDP, according to the UN. Without it, the Taliban they face a big financial hole. ⁠
⁠
Still the Islamists say they will ban production of the drug. They have been here before.⁠
⁠
Click on the link in our bio to read about the hypocrisy of the Taliban’s past efforts to control the opium economy, and why this time, it will be hard. ⁠
⁠
Credit: Wali Sabawoon/Getty Images

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist in New York, New York. May be an image of text that says 'Covid- cases in American children are at an all time high United States, confirmed covid-19 cases per 100,000 500 Age group -0-4 years -5-11 years -12-15 years -16-17 years Adults All but the youngest cohort have higher infection rate than adults 400 300 200 100 AMIJASONDJEMAMJJA 2020 2021 Sources: Centres for Disease Control and Prevention; US Census The Economist'.

node.text:
Pupils in New York have just made a full return to classrooms for the first time since the start of the pandemic. But is there reason to worry?⁠
⁠
In America, until recently adults suffered the highest infection rates. As this chart shows, today the virus is spreading fastest among young people.⁠
⁠
Cases in children are surging, accounting for more than a quarter of total infections in the country in the week ending September 2nd.⁠
⁠
Could in-person schooling accelerate the spread of the virus? To read why it depends on preventative measures, tap on the link in our bio.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist in Fort Dauphin. May be an illustration of bicycle and road.

node.text:
⁠Madagascar is one of the poorest countries on Earth. Because it has banned foreign journalists (due to covid-19), few in the outside world are aware of the famine that has left more than a million people hungry in the south of the Island. ⁠
⁠
Our correspondent evaded the ban and travelled along the grandly named Route Nationale 13 in southern Madagascar: a 110km journey from Fort Dauphin to Ambovombe. ⁠
⁠
It might as well be dubbed the road of tears, they write. ⁠
⁠
“People may be poor and angry, but ‘they have fear in their hearts’. Forget happy dancing lemurs. This is the real Madagascar.” ⁠
⁠
Click on the link in our bio to read their account of a region on the brink on famine.⁠
⁠
Illustration: @dan.will

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on September 13, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Courting influence China is becoming more assertive in international legal disputes'.

node.text:
President Xi Jinping wants China’s legal apparatus to grow more muscular in international disputes, and to reshape international legal and regulatory norms. ⁠
⁠
In areas such as patents, maritime rights, cybersecurity, sanctions and extradition battles, the Communist Party is using its legal system to safeguard and advance China’s interests in ways it has not previously done.⁠
⁠
In the past year, Chinese courts have issued sweeping orders on behalf of Chinese smartphone-makers that seek to prevent lawsuits against them in other countries over the use of foreign companies’ intellectual property. ⁠
⁠
The Communist Party says its goal is to promote “a fair and reasonable” international system of rules. ⁠
⁠
But to read why it’s increasingly clear that is not the case, tap the link in our bio.⁠
⁠
Illustration: The Economist/Getty

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist in California. May be an image of 4 people, people standing and outdoors.

node.text:
⁠On Tuesday Californian voters will decide the fate of their Democratic governor, Gavin Newsom, in a special “recall” election. ⁠
⁠
If voters recall him and elect a Republican, it could flip the US Senate. ⁠
⁠
A new governor could also appoint judges and the heads of departments, issue executive orders and veto line items on the budget. One legislator warned that replacing Mr Newsom with a Republican would produce a “lost year in California state government”.⁠
⁠
Recent polls should give Mr Newsom some comfort: The Economist’s polling average shows he has the support of roughly 54% of voters. ⁠
⁠
But it is not just his record facing scrutiny. To read why this election has called attention to the recall itself—a quirk that is being abused for partisan ends—tap on the link in our bio. ⁠
⁠
Credit: Ringo Chiu/AFP via Getty Images

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on September 13, 2021. May be an image of outdoors and text that says 'Europe Russia holds the largest military exercise in Europe for 40 years'.

node.text:
The Zapad (“west”) military exercise of 1981 was the largest and grandest exercise ever conducted by the Soviet Union, with as many as 150,000 troops from across the USSR and its alliance of satellite states, the Warsaw Pact. ⁠
⁠
Cold-war nostalgics may be pleased to learn that this year’s iteration might be larger still. ⁠
⁠
Zapad-21 could involve up to 200,000 troops from Russia, Belarus and several other countries, if Russia’s defence ministry is to be believed, outnumbering even the very largest NATO exercises of recent times. Russia’s military spending is dwarfed by America’s, and lags well behind China’s, but its armed forces have undergone a dramatic transformation over the past 15 years.⁠
⁠
Although the exercise formally runs from September 10th to 16th, troops and equipment have been flooding into exercise areas for months and some may almost certainly stay behind afterwards. ⁠
⁠
The point of exercises like Zapad is not just to refine Russia’s readiness for a big war, and its ability to wage it alongside Belarus, but also to show off that progress to would-be opponents. ⁠
⁠
Tap on the link in our bio to read why Zapad-21 reflects both the frostiness of Russia’s ties with the West, and the strengthening of those with Belarus.⁠
⁠
Credit: Press Association
